div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.
Subject to the usual 25% reduction for returning.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: THE “CONTEMPORARY REVIEW'S
div.p:
ARTICLE.
In our issue of yesterday we gave our promi- ance to an article from the "Contemporary Review" dealing with Turkey's aims on Egypt. We cannot say upon what authority the authority the author makes the remarkable statement that gossip in ‘Turkey mentions' that the English im Egypt are eo afinid of Mohimodene that they have given up their Sunday and adopted the Mahomedan day of res.” In far as we are informed, such gossip does not’ éxist,. and we Cannot believe that the Terk: are no blin that they cannot reo ignise thé real reason of oar official adoption of Friday ara ho'y day, . sad, mordover, they mist be fully aware that oatside the pale of the official world: Sunday, in recognised throughout Egypt by Christians, as the day of rest. Certainly no Mahomedan ia Egypt woald bring such a charge against ui, but would rather appraise our tolerance as the governing power of the odantey for having ’ sabmitted ourselves ootwardly and officially to their day of observance. In Tarkey sach a point has probably reosived no consideration, and moat oortaidty the Tarks will not impute cowardice trom our compliance with their o> roligioniate, Dee avy nation acoase Ragland of posillenimity on any one point | Sarely we are aoted for oar to'erant leration aa a natioa, if not aa individaals, at any rate in onr-deal ings,with any country which we govero, pro toot, or advise. Bagland has in no way fire: éworn the. principles of ite ‘religion. Are wo wrong in construing from: that passage of the artiole an insinoation on tha part of the writer himself that weonly reoogaiss the Mohamedan : Sabbath from foar! We beliove nt, bat, at ths ine time, we shoald be extremely pleased to arn from the author that we had misunder- stood him. ‘To quote another passage ; — "Now-perbaps, gonsip will tell how, when Bagliah officers were trantled by a village mob, they gave ap their weapone—the Inst disgrace of a eoldier—and 0 like halpless sheep, A Mohamedan eoontty oannotibe hell by oontuot liky that A Obrie- jan Powor which wakye,ilay ite day ot disoredited as mush as soldiers who hand over thiit weapons to assailants.” Moet vortainly in the o, ition ofa vary great many if their tellow countrynen the cfhoors made ‘very serions mistake in surrendering their arms, and it is not improbable that they are now of th opi sion’ theaselvée, bat we contend that soch an sotion did not arise from cowardice, and in this-we are-confident of receiviog the sappart of not only the Boglish in Egypt, bat of a very considerable'portion of the geeral population. The sitaation ini whioh the Boglish ‘officers were placed was most difficalt, and they immediately recognised that no effort must be spared to.propitiate the crowd and intimate that-they were ready to compensate any damage that had been done, for, be itmarked, Major Pine-Coffiti, who was, in command, thought at that momgat that they were responsible for the wounding of the foar'persona and the firing. of the girm, and hy told Lieut, Porter that-hs, the latter, had evident'y thot a woman. The first idea which aatarally ooourred to Mejor Pine-Coffia war that they shoald show their willingness to pay handsomely for the damages, and he here mado the mistake of expecting the immediate pac'f- vation of the rabble by such means, With soch sn object in.vi he.gave their gaor, which wore private and sporting “weapons by the-bye, as “a guarantes to the villagers,’ ‘and at the same time hisown watch. Had 'tha tood their ground and threatened to more than probable ‘that the natives ve made no furthorsattacks,bot Major Pine C: fia misoontraed their attitade into a rigorous demand for compensation and. thie he expressed his willingness t> afford. ‘The ab of cowardice has pot been brought againat the officera by any rection of the native vopalation, though they- have been consido-ed y Mohamedans as having foolishly mistaken the nature of the Villagers and of having die ‘ayed unnecessary pacific intents. ‘The insinva- 8 af cowardice aud the’argament that oor troops might be expected to lay down their wms in the carve of troable is absolutely an: reasonable and may be disregardéd as emanat- ng from a few hysterical individuals.

div.head: THREE STEAMERS SUNK
div.p:
A HEAVY LOSS OF LIFE.
Hono Kona, September 18.
A diasstrous typhoon struck the harbour today. Great damage has been done to ship ping. Three British steamers and one German have been sunk. T'wo-British steamers, includ- ing the Canadian Pacific Railway Company's Montesgle, foor German steamers, and an American sailing ship have been driven ashore. Many lives have been lost and a hondred persons injored. (Reuter) Hono Kona, September 18. A typboon bas wrecked three hips. Foor Prench officers have perished. ( Haves)

div.head: THE CUBAN INSURRECTION.
div.p: INSURGENTS STILL ACTIVE. New Yorx, September 18. ‘The news from Cuba is meagre, but Presi- dent Palma and his advisers appear to be making desperate efforts to come to an under standing with the insargents before the arrival of Mr. Taft. The rebel leaders, however, are disinclined to sccept the Government's pro- posals. , (Reuter) | Havana, September 18. The insurgents have destroyed several bridges belonging to « British railway. (Zeuter)

div.head: THE RUSSIAN SITUATION.
div.p:
ANARCHY IN ODESSA.
Sr. Pererssuna, September 18. The Tsar will return from bis oruise to- morrow and will attend the funeral of General ‘Trepoff. (Pexter) Sr. Pererssora, September 18. The German Ambassador here bas mado representations tothe Government with refer- ‘ence to the marder of «German manofactarer at Riga and to the general anarchy which exists in the Baltio provinces. (Feuter) Opvasa, September 13. Anvarchy reigns in the city. Ths terrorists attempted to set fire to the political priron and thot s policeman. The Roce of the “Union cf the Rassian people” is organising a hondred gangs is rely inciting people to massacre the Jews and has actually peti- tioned the Trar to remove the Prefect be- cause be is an opponent of the massacre. The situation here is typical of that existing in other cities throoghoat Russias.

div.head: BRITISH ARMY MANCEUVRES.
div.p:
DEFENDERS DRIVEN BACK.
Lospon, 8eptember 18. ‘The Irish invaders drove the British from the Sonthdowns yesterday. A feature of the marceavres is the ose of man-carrying kites for signalling and scooting purposes. Telescopic searcblights are also being used. (Reuter )

div.head: STRIKE AT GRENOBLE.
div.p: INTERVENTION BY THE TROOPS. Guenoste, September 18. The strike has resulted in a collision with the troops. About twenty persons were wound- ed. Nomerous arrests have been made. (H.)

div.p: Paris, September 18. The grest foresta near Cannes are on fire. Already upwards cf 40,000 screa have been borned, Troops are endesavonring to limit the fire, which is fanned bys high wird. (7’euter)

div.head: ARAB BLOODSTOCK
div.p: The United States Governmet seems to attach more importance to Arab stock in horses than | that of any other country. An sccredited agent _of the United States G vernment recent!y pas- sed throogh France for ‘Turkey, and news has jnst been reeeived st the American Embassy that as the resolt of credentials from the Washington Departinent of State and from Mr, Rooseve!t, thisgentleman had obtained from the ‘Torkish Goveroment a permit to export from six to eight stallione—a permit for such » nomber not having been previously given for qoarter of a century. In all, fourteen to twenty horses of the finest strain will’be secured, and it is hoped that before long they will arrive at | Marseilles on their way to America.

div.head: MUTINY ON A TROOPSHIP
div.p:
H.M.S. Venus, which left Alexandria unex '| bectedly yesterday morning for Port Said, was summoned thither in order to be in readiness to cope with a'matiay of Syrian convicts on board the Turkish transport Assyr at- Port Said. Io fact a0 sarioas was the aspect of effairs st the time that orders were sent to recsll the Lasoasbire Fasiliers, who were engaged in field manwavres in the desert to retarn “at once and to entrain at Port Said. Three handred roonda of ammanition were given to each man. They retorned from the mar cavres, .bat the orders were coantermanded st the Isst moment. The origin of the oatbreak ‘was as follows : — The passengers of the Assyr, which bad arrived that morning from Stamboal and Beyront, consisted of several detachments of ‘Torkish troops and two hundred Syrians, who a8 convicts were being exiled to Yemen, for service against the Arab rebels. The Syrians had joined the Assyr at Beyrout, and on the way to Port Said bad told the commander that they would revolt if he refased to retarn on arrival at Port Said. The commander took no notiog of the threats, whereopon, on arrival at Port Said, the motineers made an attack on the commander. The Tarks, however, remsined loyal, aod arming themselves with swords, sticks, ropes, and anything they could lay hands upon, assailed the Syrians. Inthe pitched battle which ensoed six Tarkish soldiers were killed, and » hundred wounded, inclading the commander. Some of the officers fled for their lives. The port police intervened and by half past two order was restored. The Aseyr bi displacement of 3,000 tons, with! considerable cargo &ocommodation and is gne of the oldest tradyports in the pres service. Ne
THE COMPTOIR FINANCIER. The Comptoir Financier de |'Ezypte bas opened s London branch. This is an impor! nt development, as in all probability thi brauch will be the “point d’appui” for the important new bank which the Comptoir will Isonch shortly. The board of directors of the Comptoir bas slso spproved of the scheme of opening a branch at Liverpool. We understand that a dividend of twelve per cant. will be declared for the first year's working and a dividend of £2 for the found- ers’ shares. Considerable sams will be placed to the various reserve fands.
THE LEVANT LINE. It is expected thats dividend of at least five per cent will be decisrad on the first year's working of the Bgypt and Levant Line. As there shares are held in great num bers locally, it is surprising that vo applioa- cation has yet been made for » qaotation on the Alexandria Boprse.
DELTA LIGHT RAILWAY CO. The Delta Light Rai present time increasing its railway system by the constractior of two important lines in the Gharbieb province and also a network of lines among the quarrie: the east of Cairo. The line from Sakha to Sidi Salem’ will be shortly finished and the rails are already down. It will be thirty kilometres. in length, and will open apa fast developing country. The li from Tirah to Bileah ia about fifteen kilometres in length and will form s very osefal conneo- tion. The line is rapidly approsching comple- tion. The lines connecting the Easte-n quarries of Cairo will ran to ¢épots at Abbassieh, Bab ol Hasanieh, Bab el Nasir and the end of the Moosky street. These lines will supply the wsnts of Cairo in ba g material and will considerably minimise the croglty and over- loading which now goes on in regard to the beasts of barthen engaged on the quarry work,
UM RUS GOLD MINES. ~ The resalts of the ordinary clean-up for Augost at the Um-Ros Mines were aa follows : 692 tons of ore were crashed, 636 oz. of bar gold wore prod: ced, valued at £2,294 ; 554 tons of tailings storat of an average assay value of 3dwt. per ton.
EGYPT'S CIGARETTE TRADE. Last month a decided falling-off was shown ‘in the export of cigarettes from Bgypt,the total figares only amounted to 86,981 kilos, as com- pared with 61,679 kilos. in Angost 1905, and 1s deorrase of 22.804 kilos, is also reported for the total exports since the Ist. of Janoary. Germany is mainly responsible for this oonsid- erable decrease, the difference between Au- gust 1906 and 1905 bei 24,644 kilos, Bogland imported an exceas of 1,023 lat montb, bat since the Ist of Janoary » falling off of 1,586 kilos, is shown, France gives an increase for this period of 1,801 kilor., Holland incressed her trade by 1,734 kilos., while Switzerland imported 9,210 kilos. lose than daring the corresponding period of last year.

div.head: PORT SATD SALT ASSOCIATION.
div.p:
LOCAL EFFECTS OF COMBINE.
‘The Port Said Salt Association, which has s considerable export business with Indi profit considerably by the new British Salt Combine whose object is to increase tha price of salt especially in Calcutta and other Par. East ports. The latest English newspapers give the following details of the Britirh Salt Combine:— It was ascertained yesterday that an amal gamation by which the British salt~ ontpat distribotion and prices will be regalated is now an accomplished fact, and bas been registered ander the name of the North-Western Salt Company. Capital, amounting to £10.000, bas been subscribed by the salt manufacturers themselves A seoretary bas been appointed, and, a8 far as oan be learned, the Salt Union and practically every outside manofsctarer in the kingdom are parties to the agreement. Presomably, salt) will be distributed from one central office. Some aathorities dectare that the ‘arrangements will be of enormous advan: tage to both the Salt Union and outside makers. Representatives of the salt trade,interviewed last night, declared that the new amalgamation registered as the North-Western Salt Company ill not prejadics the general public or aftect prices to consomers. Price-cutting and over- loaded markets have for years reduced the profits, and thoosands of tons of white and tock ealt have been sold at home and abroad below the cost of production. India ealt has been bonded and the variation of freights has proved rainous. All orders will now be sent to the new compacy for execation. The Directors will control the outpat and pricss, and profits will be distributed pro rats half yearly: Many contraote still exist which will prevent the fall benefits of the amalgamation being immediately realised, bot the combice will, it is said, prove the salvation ot the trade. Ths Directors have been appointed. The S:lt Union nominated Messrs, Cox and Young, and a large number of other firms nominated one each. Workiog arrangements, it is hoped will be made with foreign competitors.
DESERT TRACTION.
A REMARKABLE EXPERIMENT.
Some important trials of the new desert boat are coming off on Sanday next at Abbas- sieh, chen the first wind-motor will make ita debut in Egypt. It ix » 24 foot ontter-abaped craft with ten foot beam with iron frame work and ron oa iron spider wheels. These craft, which are well-known in the California desert and in England at Whitby, bave attained ‘a rate of forty aa hour. The craft in question was built by Mr. Boyos in Cairo and has been oconstracted at the'reqnest of Mr. William C. Hornblower. Great developments are expected from this new mode of traction in Egypt, which is destined,’ it is said, to revolutionise devert travel.
THE NEW FRENCH CONSULATB.
The designs for the new French Consualate at Alexsodria, which is to be situated on the quays near the Gsneral Post Office and opposite the new Gouvernorat buildings, are to be taken in hand at once and to-morrow M. Lambert, the architect appointed by the French Govern- ment for the parposs, is arriving bere from Venice by the Florio Robst-ino steamer. This gentleman is the architest of the Chateano, Veraeilles, is s well kaowa Parisian archi: teot. He is/ the brother-in-law df M. Pierre Girard, Freoch Consal at Alexandria. As soon as thedesicos sre approved, the work of con- straction will be commenced. Notbiog bas as yet been decided as to what is t> be done with the existing French Consulate, batowing to the ris in real property it will probably be sold.
ITALIAN NATIONAL FRTE.
To-morrow evenings grand night féto will be beld at San Stefano Casino for the benefit ofthe Italian Société de Bienfaissnce, com- mencing at 9.30 p.m. The cbief attractions will be the illomiontion of the terrace a /a venitienne, » concert by the Greek Philharmonic Booiety, and a variety eutertainment in the thestre andor the patronage of the Italian 1. Fire balloons will be sent op at in- tervals from the terrace,and on the conclasion of the entertainmgats there will be a fire work display. At Cairo the Brmete Novelli Society will hold s /éte champdére at Kaar-el-Nil, com- menoing at 4.30 p.m., of which the following is the programms:—donkey-race, sack-race, greasy pole climbing, for all of which events a price of P.'T. 100 will be given, vatious games, and @ special performance at the Ambassa- dears theatre. By kind permission of Major 0. J. L. David- son, D. 8. 0,, Commanding, and officers, the Band of the Ynd Battalion Reyal Inniskilling Fasiliers under the taton of Mr. R. Wateon Ramsey will play a releotion of mosio during the evening on the Kasr el: Nil Terrace.
STEAMER MOVEMENT.
The Kbedivisl mail wteamabip Assonan will leave Alexandria at 4 p.m, on Satorday and Port Said at 4 pm. on Sonday for Jaffa, Caiffa, Beyrouth, Tripoli, Mersin, and Alox- andretta.

div.head: MUSTAPHA PASHA KAMEL.
div.p:
MINISTERIAL ORGAN’S SUPPORT.
The “Tribune” makes the following remarks on the letter from Mastapha, Pasha Kamel, whioh'it pablished,and which we reprodaced on Monday. The ‘article is of interest »8 showing the standpoint of that section of the Radical party which is not adverse to giving him tome support. ‘The point of view is fall of hamoar and the implication that the bratal outrage at Denish: wai was doe to "the material and intellectoal renaissance” and “a oertain moral uplifting” of the fellah is» magnificant example of topay. tarvy reasoning :— We print to-day a letter in which Mustafe Kamel Pesha, the Bditor of “Bl Lewa,” and one of the leaders of the younger Egyp comments upon the affair, We that few Boglishmen will feel that w adequate anawer to his claim that jastioe has been violated. Neither is it possible to main: tain on the evidence that facaticiom had any part in the oatrage. Let os suppose that a Protestant farmer in Ireland, whose domestio pigeons had been shot by a Catholic sporta- man, had besten him after he had, seen his wife wounded and his barn set on fire. Should we have acoosed him of fanaticism, or ascribed his resentment to religious hatred! Bot, in- deed, after the proseoutor's explanation that the whole affair was due to the Tesen{ment osused by a previous trespass, the soggestion of fanaticism must be abandoned. The’ plain facts of the case are that the Baropean ‘colony were alarmed not becanse the natives had shown fanaticism, bat simply because they had dared to resent an injory. It was this display of indeperdence that startled them. They had been aconstomed to the fellah of the old days, who, as the writer in the “Temps” pat it, never dared to raise his yes from the ground, They bad watched his in- crease of prosperity and edacation ; they had seen him take eagerly to the reading of news- papers, and they had not reflected that this material and intelieotoal renaissance implied atthe rame time a ocertsin moral uplifting. ‘The fellsh had beoome a man,.undor Britich rale, and the rulers bad forgotten that he would acquire the passions with the rights of aman. The same thing has happened where- ever Jews, dowotrodden for centaries, patient of irjaries, and timid in expressing resent: ment, bave dared at last to claim the privile- ges of citizens. The fatare of Bgypt will be clouded and stormy, unless its governors at |sst appreciate that the splendid work they have accomplished has bred a new race which demands some recognition of its progress.” The letter from the Egyptian leader mast be read with sympathy, though with « certain reserve. He has been acoased of fomenting fanaticism, bat as yet no one has printed a single extract from his newspaper. which supports this charge: He is certainly Tarcophil, but we know of no oe to prove that he really desires to restore T'arkish rule in Egypt. Od the other hand, it is olear that though he may have been driven by the lack of sympathy which. be thinks be detects in the |Bogliah oconpation to look to Constastinople for sopport, his programme ia widely differeat from that of the Palace clique which directs | the Pan-Islamio movement there. -He asks for some beginning of that representative govern- ment which Lord Dafferin promised s quarter of acentary sgo. He oriticizes the Boglish policy, which, he thinks, neglected elementary edacation, and so destroyed the democratic character of native society. Lastly, he:is anxious to restore the great Moslem University of Iodis, on a modern, scientific basis. We oan see in this programme nothing fanatical, nothing anti-Baropean, nothing retrograde. The Mohamedan world, striving for a renaiss- ance oa such lines, is eatitled to as mach sympathy and as mooch assistance as the Christian world of the Balkans and the heathen world of Japan. This movement. is the obild of Baropesn civilisation ; it will tarn against it only if it finds its foster-parent ankind.” ‘Al Moayads" Opinicn, “Al Moayad” in it irnue of Sanday maker a vigorous attack on Mostapha Pasha Kamel aod the policy of his newspaper “Al Lews.” Sheikh Aly Youssel's organ, says :— “As we aro all responsible for oor acta as Journalists we should do our bert to cheok at erring conlrére from going too far in his folly and rash-aod onwise policy, which will have tha worst effect opon the nation and cause mach harm to it, All oor readers know what was the idea of Lord Cromer when he attsoked the lelamio Presa in the course of his writings regarding the! Akaba affair, and they. also know the raasons for that attack. Daring the Akaba difficulty the proprietors of ‘Al Lewa” charged their fellow journalists with treachery and cowardice, beoause none of them joined theni in their onwise polioy with the exception ‘Al Umme,’ edited by Sheikh BI Sharbatly, which annonnced the arrival of threa Turkish battalions at No. 8 Pal while the former reported that scodrding to information received by Ghazi Mokhtar Pasha, eighty thousand ‘Torkish troops were at the door of en this romour was gab waren P} INR that the report had been submitted before publication to Mukhtar Pasha, who the information, and who continoed “Al-Lews,” ia striving to fan life into Pan Ielamiem in Rgypt. Boob a statement led Lord Cromer to consider the publications of the native papora as falaa and fanatical, -avd it was for this reason that he threatened the Press with the sappression of ita liberty. “Snob consrquences have placed um in w very critical position, and so it behoves us to be carefal and attentive, and we bave to draw the attention of ovr oonfidres to e that might cause the bringing of charges against us."

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p:
Lord Errington left London lsat week ia order to join Lord Cromer in Scotland.
Mr. Machell, Adviser to the Ministry cf the Interior, is expectet to arrive in Cairo on the 15th prox. from Boglanil.
The unexpected relapse of the Mondir of Keneb after, he had resnmed his official doties has agait-ted to the report that Mastaphe Bey Yassim will be allowed to resign his position on the return of Mr. Machell from Bogland. If this isso, thers will- be in conseqoence a Lum- ber of changes among the moadire and sab- mondirs.
Mabmoud Nedim Pasha was received in andience by the Khedive during his Highness's recent visit to Vienna.
M. Girard, Prench Consul-Genere!, arrived. at Alexandria this morning from Barope.
Mr. Goscheo, private seorstary to the Minister of Pcblio Works, has retarned to Cairo.
Khalil Pasha Hamada, Director of the local custom-house, arrived at Alexandria yesterday afternoon on his retarn from Beyroat.
Maitre Carton de Wiart arrived at Port Said yesterday by the P. and 0. 8.9 Arabia and proceeded direct to Cairo, _
‘The Rev. and Mra, N. Odeb arrived at Port Baid yesterday from Bagland by the Nord. deatecber Lloyd 8.8, Printws Alice, and continued atraight to Cairo.
Major W. Bromilow, Ist Battalion Dablin Posiliers, who arrived at Port Said last woek by the P. and 0. 8.8.Britannia, hss joined the onit at Alexandria.
Bxteosion of leave until Ootober 21 has been granted to Lieut. C. W. Gaitekell, Let Battalion Lancashire Posiliers, on the recom- mendation of a medical board.
Piba Bey is staying at the Grand Hotel, Lausanne. +
Sassoan Bay, of Cairo, bas arrived at the Sohweirsrbof, Falla of the Rhine.
It -is with great regret thit we learn of the death of Dr. F. Zagores, the distin- gaished Cairo ocalist, atthe age of 46 years, We cffer our sinceré condolences to the many members of the bereaved family.
The following visitors sre staying at the Bean Rivage Hotel, Ramleb :— Dr. and Mra, Kactzky aod family, Mr. and Mme A. Midari, Mr. B. Rolo, Mr. T. Gatt, Mr. and, Mra. A. Wells, Misi A. Gastar, Mr. and Mis. Ugo Morpurgo and family, Misa B. Padden,’ Mise @. Way;; Mr. H. Gsttao, Mr. and Mrs. H. Zirinansi, Mr. and Mra. 1. Heffis, Mr. J ames Watson, Mrs. L. Spenoe, Mr. -A. Hove, Mr. and Mra. T. Honsley, Mr. and Mes. W. Alden, Mr A. Smith.

Voici maintenant les détails poar l'eovoi da toates marchandises an Soudan, par voie fir vials (Nil): D’Alexandrie 4 Chellal (cstaracce, aprés Anssaan) par chemin de fer égyptien, suivant tarif. Ds Chellal a Wadi Hs'fs par chaloapes & vapeur (Cook, Dalts et autres) & raison de P.T. 1 fe cantar. Cook qvi n’avait pss de coo- currents a0 commencement, faisait payer P.T. 3. De Wadi-Halfs a Khartoam North (station Halfaya, avant Omdorman) par chemin de fer do Soudan, suivant’ tarif, Los transitsires de Wadi-Halfa prencent P.T. 1 le Cantar, com- mission et tous frais compris. De Khartoum Nerth & Omdarman oo 4 Kbartoam City, par chaloape & vapear, coiit da transport, y compris les frais et ls cow- mission do transitaixe de P.T. 3 4 P.T. 6 le cantar, suivant ls saison, |e quantité et l'état du Nil. Los tarifs de chemins de fer du Soudan peuvent étre achetés chez les agents do gou- vernement & Alexandrie ou a0 Caire. Par scite des nombreox transbortements que la marchandise doit subir, il fact toojoars emballer trés soigneosement. La gomme est emballée en doubles ssos forts. Le governement anglo-scudsoais, en éts bliseant les tarifs de la noovelle ligoe Khar toom North & Port-Soadan, s manifestement voula favoriser cet'e dernitre ac détriment du transport par voie flaviale préoédemment employé, et caci afia de concentrer toat le commoroa du Soadan aveo I'Earope, dans le nouvean port. Ceperidant, malgré I'svantage des tarifs de la noave'le ligne (Port Soadac Mer Ronge) plosiears négociante emploier t encore Is voie primitive q1i, qaoiqne cottant piuscher, lear permat d'avoir tooj rare levr msrcbandise dans an laps de temps détermiré et en bon état, ceqni n'est pas tonjours le cas poor Is ligne de Port Soudan ci des vols, dit-on, se sont récemment produits, sans qu'on ait po en établirles resyonaabilités, Eo oxtre, los imondstions récentes ont fait dévier le- rails, e¢ qaia prodait un retard, trés préjadi ciable:poar an article sojet & tant de flactus. tions de prix. div.head: MARCHE DE MINET-EL-BASSAL
div.p:

div.head: EGYPTIAN RAILWAYS.
div.p:
THE TRAFFIC DEPARTMENT.
The coaching receipta for 19.5 show an in eresre of LE. 128,441 over thy previous year or 10.8 per cert. ‘The namber carried in 1905 was 20,036,42. As against 17,724,922 in 144, an increase o} 2,311,502, or 13 per cent. The passenger train kilomet-age am unted t> 7 890,362 kilomatres, compared with 6 985,103 in 1904, a9 increase of 905,258 train kilometres, or 12.9 per cant. The receipts per passenger train kilomatre were 167 milliemes in 1905, compared witb 170 milliemos in 1904, a desrenss of 3 milliemes, or 1.7 par cent. The receipts per passenger carried amounted to 66 milliemes, ax against 67 milliemes in 1904 ‘The slight decrease in the coaching earnings Per train kilometre may be a‘tribated to the additional trains pot into service, which can- not be expro'ed to earn as mach as long eatab- lished services; and to perishab'es, which were formerly classed ax parcel being now inolnded as goods tr fli: The ten powerfal engines received daring the year have enabled the railways to slmovt entirely stop the objectionable practice of ranning traina with two engines. | Extra Trains. wenty-three addiiooal pss:eoger trains ded to the daily time table, and several ing services were considerably extended, ‘This was especially the case in Upper Egypt, where the extra daily services amounted to 1,519 kilometres, Bytween Loxor and Assooan & new mixad service wis pat into operation, with satisfactory resnits, Train Service Improved. ‘She servives to and from Saez’ have been srcelersted for the same reason. Tae timings batwoan Mansoorah and Cairo, via Zsgarig, bave been revised and improved. An additional service has baan arranged to and from the Payoum. Toe afternoon express services from Cairo to Alexsndcia have besa rearranged snd improved. Punotualtty, Owing tw enginearing operations, the punoctaality of the trains on the Upper Egypt line was not so satisfactory as daring the preceding year, The delays have, tq some extent, been radaosd by opening new block posts, and providing additional siding accom. modation. With the arrival of uew eagives the paactual- ity of trains in Lower Bgypt has so fi proved that the proportion of late arrivals is very small. : Speed of Trains. ‘Tne average b»kad speed of passengor trains, which io fiva years had riven from eighteen to over twenty three miles an boar, bas fallen to «small fraction ander tweaty- three, owing to the increase in the propor- tion of stoppiog trains. On the branoh lines it bas been possible to improve the speed of certain trains by converting them from ‘Mixed” to “Passenger,” Accidents. ‘Toere ts no serious digagter to record ducing 1905, bute few minor accidents occarred to pamergar trains, Oa Jane 20th the tender and some vehicles of train No. 13 (9.30 a.m. Cairo fo Alex andris) were derailed near the Tewfikieh Bridge, causing some damage to the bridge ‘The derailment was due to some platelayars ‘who were carrying out eogineering work. Ou Ootober 2ad, goods train No, 81 overran Kassassin Station daring » fog. Jast at this time train No. 38 arrived from Mahsamab, and a colisivn took place resolting ‘in the derailment ot both trains. Sixteen railway employés and seven passengers were slightly injored. Oo Ostober 12°h, train No. 210 collided with a nomber of tracks which were being shanted st Kafr-el Zsyat station. Ten trocks were derailed and damsged, and five persons were injared. On November 29:b, an irrigation bank barat near Abou Nowros, readering the Masraf-el- Guizeh bridge unsafe for traffix. Passengers had to be transhipped from one train to another until December 2nd, when normal workiog was re-omed Ou Decamber 17th, train Nog. 1{4 and 2.9 collided at Chibioe! Kanater, owing to the points having been wrongly set; both engines and some rolling stock were damaged, and five persons wore slightly injured Oo December 19 b an accident occurred at Fayed between passenger train No. 105 and goods train No. 334. This was also the resalt of the points being wrongly set. One railway employee was killed, four passengora wore slightly inj red, aud one seriously injorod. New stations. Five uew stations were opened for passenger trofiis in 1905, viz, Basbtil, Birrag, Kagong, Sandaubour snd Boorgayab, Seven halts were converted into crossing stations. Lighting. Doring 1905, there has been a marked improvement in the general lighting of the rei waye. 43 coaches have been fitted with gas, and the installation of Pintsch's gas fur carriages ravning on branch lines bas 'been commenerd Foarteen new coaches were fitted with Stone's rystom of electric light. A vew pattern of borner for oil lamps has been introduced, by means of which some economy bas been flected. A considerable namber of “Lox’ Jamps have been installed during the year and have viven Fati«faction ; ’4 stations ara now lighted with these lamps, including all the stations on the Matarieh Line. A Inrgo vomber of signal, diso, and other Inmps have been made by tho Lighting Dapart ment at less oost than prices qaoted by Barop eon firms. Owirg to the grost increase in the work of thi Depsrtmont it has been found necessary to increase the staff.

div.head: MISSIONARIES IN THE SUDAN.
div.p:
Continning bis account of missiop work in /the Sudan, a missionary contributes an article ) “The Standard,” from which wa quote the following extract - — ‘The strongest of all the Nile tribes in the apper Nile have «charming manner of Slaying alive their enemies: ; this has been dons within the Inst soven years, Two Eoglishmen, paying 4 peacefal visit to thia tribe, about four years '8g0, escaped slinost by a miracle from death by the eame ‘harming manner.” It was not long bsfore the doctor of the mission bad some experience of the native crue'ty. He was attending « poor old wom too werk to leave her hat, who showed sig f improvement after treatment. -Oo going to tha hot with medicine, he was mach sorprised to find a man in the hat fyrbid admission. Being « hefty Christian, the doctor ma show of determination to save the woman, at which the men row up and barred the way with their spears. After expressing himself as strongly as possible in the Dinka language, he left the medicine near the hat and went away. When be went next day they ssid abe! bad died, and that they had thrown the body in the river. No Hereafter. It hascoften been ssid that mankind every- where has some idea of lite after desth ; but & branch of the Bari tribe, which inhabits the country south of Darfur, seems tobe ane: exception to this. In marching along the river bank north of Monggslla, two of the party came to a emall fishing village where the people scemed to be of a low organism. Questioned as to what hap- pened to them death: ‘We throw them into the river,” ‘Ab, bat after that 1” “The crocodiles are many." ‘Bat then; what can! happen after cfooodiles 1” Leu ghteh Yet they did have an, ides that there were ap\rits, most of them evil, but they wore not sure chether thase-wore the ep rita of departed, When the bamp was arranged, and there was breathing time enoogh to look round and see the kind ot place in which they bad oast sochor, the missionaries foand themselves in the midst of a very scanty popalation (only « hondred and fifty within a radios of eight miles). ‘This was disappointing, bat what troubled them more wore ths myriads of malaria breod- ing morqritoes which infested theosmy. The outlook war not promising for sia healthy ( young Eyglishmen —not. muoh aoope for work by day and worried by moaqnitoes by night, y Two of the older bands at the work determined to march inland and spy ont the land, and attor six days’ joarney thay oame back like Joshas and Caleb, with an excellent report, Thirteen miles inland they foond a high j platesa, sboat a handred and fifty feet abova j the river level, where they saw thousands of } Dinkas, with large herds of fine oattle and , wiles of cyltivated ground, and, best of all, na! mosquitoes. They regeivad a great walooma from the people, who, though stark naked aud ! simple in thair ways, perfectly anderatood the \* difference between the Turks and the Koglish, The Medicine Man To fact, three ‘British officers at different times bad visited them, and impressed these people by their justice and kindnes:, and these had to!d them that some day white men would come and tell them of the white _ man’s God. (These « flicers oaght to be-asked to speak at Bxeter Hall.) The doctor was mach in request, crowds of people attendicg him at every stop. ping place, bringing their sick and maimed. It was pathetic to see what confidence they had in the doctor almost from the first, the chief reason being that the doctor had some eighteen years’ experience of Africans, and knew bow to deal with them. There were a few drawbsoks, one of which was the scarcity of water. Having no idea of wells, the native resorted to the primitive and simple method of forming huge poola of rainwater and scooping out- the c'ay asthe water became exhausted. The poola wera hedged in by thorn bushes to keep oat the cattle, but the Diokas themselves perform their ablations in these reservoirs. It was rather disc nserting to be hailed in a most fnendly way by s Dinka splashing aboot enjoying a bath in what you koew to be your only sapply for dricking and making tes, Bat Joshaa and Caleb declared they grew quite used to the taste cf Dinka and water. Meteoric Fetish. In their jwanderings they bad@foand ont something of the religion of the people, which was mosttintereating. In a hot depecially set apart there is a spear which the natives deslare came down’ from the clouds in a than derstorm many years ago.
The people stand in great awe and dread of this spear ; only two people are allowed to go near—tho chief, Beor, and the ‘Jao!,” whiob, in the Dinks language, means a “speaker.” These two only can interpret the messages of the 9 sacred spear. In times of danger trom raids or dronght or disease or cattle plague the “lool” reeks counsel of the sacred spear. Prom what C the “lool” himself said, he evidently goes into m a kind of trance, and doring this trance bis A atterances are the morsages of Heaven through a1 this sxcred medium.

div.p:
(Prom ovr Cormesp INDENT, ) London, Saptomber 8. Oaths reduction of the Lancashire Fosi- lier, Mrjor F.C.L: Logan, ist Battalion, Cairo, has been: placed on half-pay.
Those who knew Major W. BE. O'Leary, of the Royal Irish flea, when he waa attached to the Bgyptian Army in the “nineties” will regret to learn that ho has to goon halfpay pro. tem. owing to ill health. He saw service in the Dongola expedition, 1895, the Nile expedition, 1897-98, and the South Afrio- an. war. i
The Egyptian draft of the 6th Toniskilling Dragoons, consisting of 50 non-commissioned officers and men ander Lieotenant (. Mac G. Danbsr, 20th Hussars (appciated aide-de- camp to Major General G. M. Ballcok, com- manding the Britigh troops in Barb’) and Second Lieutenant /G. C. Nelson (who'ts join- ing the loniekillings on first appoiotment) ill embark on the transport Sicilia at South- ampton on ths 29th inst, for Alexandria, The eame liner will bring oat the 8rd Battal- ion Coldstresm Ga: to Cairo, and on the retorn journey, the Ist Battalion Lancashire Pasiliers from Kzypt to Malt, and the let Battalion Rifls Brigade from Malta to Belfast.
Tho Ist Battalion Royal Inniskilling Fasi- marched into Victoria Barracks, Be'fast, yesterday afternoon abont 1-30 after ten weeks sojourn in Ballykinlar camp, where it was in brigade. with the 2nd Battalion P.W.O. Weat Yorkshire Regiment. The Ianiskillings looked very fit after sq prolongad a stay by the breesy Irish ses. The battalion railed from Tollymorry, and, preo:ded by the regimental band and the droms, marched from County Dowo station to the barracks, aoccmpanied by slaty» oawd of interested people. It was originelly arranged that the battalion woold leave Ballykiolar on the 15th September and march for the remaiving fifteen days of the month through Voanty Down over the route recently travelled by the 5th Battalion Royal Irish Refiss, bat this was csnoelled last week. | Colonel @. M. Mackerzie, commanding the Joniskillings, retorned from leave yesterday aud rosomed command of the battalion,
Lieutenant G. J. Ryan, Royal Monster Pusi ow Bimbashi commanding No. 4 Company Camel Corpr, Bgyption Army, bas bsen promoted captain in the Fasiliers, and remains with the Khedive's army on promo: tion. Captain Ryan got his commission in the | Pasiliera in September 1897. He was with the Mounted [nfantry in the Soath African War, 1899-1901, aud saw a good deal of fight- ing in the Transvaal, Cape Colony and Orange Kiver Colony, inolading the relief of Kim- berley, acd tha actions of Bolfaat and Modder River.
It is understood that tho heavy slashing ord with which onr cavalry mex now armed will be disoarded »f/an early date, and replaced by « mach lighter oat and thrast sword, ‘The weapon will be)a little longer than the present ove. It tw@ curious fact that slthough the thrast is maob more deadly than the cot, the AngloBaxon haa never taken kindly to it, aa in action be instinotively bes h that mascolarity which is a distinctive featore cf his race. It ia jast as carious that the Celt, with the exception of) the Irishman and Highlander, prefers. the Jeadly throst.
The cruiser Talbot completed to fall strength | | ‘o-day at Chathash, and proceeded to Devon- | ort, where she will tarn over her crew to the roiser Minerva, which is to be recommis- jioned by Captain H. J. L. Clarke for another wo years spell with the Mediterranean fleet, | | )wing to the exceptional service of all hands jaring the Tabah incident, the crew has been | ; granted an additional week's leave. The Minerva will leave for ber station about the 2th inst.
The work of Hating the Dreadnonght oat | § of dock at Portsmouth having basen snoceas ally‘acoomplished, « very effort is being made o have her finished as qiiokly'as possible so hat her trials may be commenced withont nnecesaary delay. The armament ia all in sition with the exception of the battery of 2-pounder quick firers.
A third new coastal torpedo-bost destroyer as juat beea launched at the yard of Messrs. 8, White and Co, Bast Cowes, the other oats Isonobed at this work being the Cricket | } nd Dragor fly. ‘I'he new destroyer, which has een named the Firefly, has a displacement of | § 30 tons, messures 170 feet in length, with a eam of 19 feet, and her water tube boilers! ‘ re expected to give arflivient pressore to evelop & speed of 26 knota in her turbines, ‘he boilers are of the White Forster type.
Every one ia delighted to loarn that Lord Charles Beresford his been selected to oom: mand the Channel Fleet when Admiral Sir A. K. Wilson, V.C., vacates the command onder the roles next March, ‘The gallant Irishman is as cheery in action an ho in out of it, and “well done, Condor” will remain a tobword whilst Britain remains a Power. What he does not know about « war ship is hardly worth logging. It in over 47 years since he donred the uavy blue and since then be his served on overy station ‘of oor world wido E npire, and eaw fighting wherever that laxory was to be hid. He knows China and Japan like a book, and it ia mt too much to aay that our little allies of the Far Bast ad- mire him a8 much as they revero their own Togo. ‘Tho groatly impéjived and sugmouted Channel fleet could nat havea better Com- mander-in-Ghief than "Lord Charley.”

div.head: Notice. SUDAN GOVERNMENT
div.p: Disposal of Building Sites at Port Sudan The Sudan Government will shortly dispose by Tender of about 400 Building Sites at Port Sudan.
The sites will be Leasehold held at Annual Rents on Building Lease for Eighty Years from 1st January, 1907. Rents will be payable only from date of acceptance of Tender.
The Lease will be Perpetually Renewable at Revised Rents fixed in default of Agreement by Arbitration at the end of each term of years.
In fixing the revised rents the value of Buildings erected by Leases will Not be regarded as a ground for Increase of Rent.

Example: If a plot leased for a term of 80 years from 1st January 1907 then on the expiration of that term the Lease will have a right (subject to observance of his convenant etc.) to obtain a fresh lease for a further period of 80 years at a revised rent, and so on in perpetuity. The revised rent will be calculated on the value the site would bear if it were vacant building lands.
Officers are invited of Premium for the Purchase of the above mentioned leasehold sites.
All offers must be made by Tender, on the forms issued by the Sudan Government, and must be received at Khartoum not later than 1st January 1907.

Particulars of the sites offered, Plan of the Town, Conditions of Tender and Sale, Form of Tender, specimen Form of Lease, etc., will on and after October 1st 1906 be open to inspection at the following places during the usual business hours.
Khartoum: *Office of Director of Agricultures and Lands (T) and Office of Governor of Khartoum Province.
Cairo: *Office of Sudan Agent (T)
Port Sudan: Office of Inspector (Government Office)(T)
Soaking: Office of Governor of Red Sea Province.
El Damer: Office of Governor of Berber Province
Athara: Office of Director of Railways.
Alexandria: Office of Mr. Macpherson Grant
Port Said: Office of Dixon Bey, War Office Representative
London: *Office of Col. Western, Broadway Chambers, Westminster, and the Sudan Court, Imperial Institute
Suez: Office of Capt. Falcones, War Office Representative

For the convenience of intending purchasers the Conditions of Tender and Sale have been translated into Arabic and French and copies of the translations into either language will be obtainable after 1st October 1906 on payment of 5 P.T. per copy at the Offices in the above list which are distinguished by a capital T.
Further information will be obtainable after the publication of the above-mentioned documents on application in writing to The Director of Agriculture and Lands, Khartoum.
*Copies of the Documents will be obtainable after 1st October 1906 on payment of 5 P.T. or 1 Shilling per copy at the Office marked with an asterisk.

div.head: Supplement Commercial et Financier.
div.p: De "L'Egyptian Gazette"

Le Supplément Commercial et Financier de l' "Egyptian Gazette" paraît chaque Samed à midi, de façon à pouvoir être expédié par le paquebot autrichien. Il contient des revues complètes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marché des valeurs; les dernières statistiques jusqu'à la veille de sa publication: des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des dépêches officielles envoyées à la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc etc
L'abonnement pour une année en Egypte coûte 1 L.E. y compris les frais de poste; pour l'étranger 10 P.T. de port en sus.

div.head: GOUVERNEMENT DU SOUDAN Concessions de Terrains a Batir a Port-Soudan
div.p: AVIS
Le Gouvernement du Soudan va prochaine ment disposer, par voie d'-djudication d’eu viron 400 parcelles de terrains a batir à Port- Soudan.

Les dites parcelles seront données à bail emphytéotique, pour une dorés de 80 années au partir du ler Jauvier 1907, moyennant loyes annuel, a charge pour le locataire de batir. La loyer ne sera payable qu’à partir de la date de l’acceptation de l’oftre.
Les baux seront renouvelables a perpétuités, moyennant un loyer variable filé a la fin di chique terme, soit d’accord, soit par arbitrage.
Eu fixant le nouveau loyer, la valeur des batirments élevés par le locataire ne sera pau considérée comme un motif d’angmentation de loyer.

EXEMPLE: Si une parcelle de terrain est louée pour une dorée de 80 années a partir du 1er Janvier 1907. Dans ce cas, a l’expiration des es délai, le locataire aura un droit (A condition d’observar les conditions du bail) d’obtenir no nouyean bail pour one nouvelle période de 80 années, moyennant un loyal modifié, et ainsi de saits a perpétuité.
Le loyer modifié sera calcu;é aur la valeur du terrain, s'il était libre de construction

Des offres sont demandées pour les baux emphytéotiqus dont s'agit ; osa offres devront mentionner 1a prime que le soumissionnaire est disposé A payer au comptant en sus des loyers annuels établis pour chaoun des lots. La dite prime devra être payée en un seul versement a la signature du contrat de bail.
Toutes offres doivent être faites par sonmission, sur les formules dressées par le Gouvernement du Soudan, et doivant être reçues a Khartoum avant le 1er Janvier 1907.

Le détail des terrains oflarta, le plan delà ville, les conditions de l’adjod oation et de la ounoesrion, la formn’e de soumission, spér fi oa- tion do bail, sere .t A ta disposition do Public A partir do 1er Octobre 1906, aux lieux ci- après indiqué*, dorant les heures de bureau.
